I have found that the best way to do this is probably with one's own 
Test=
Listener instance.

I found the facilities for pointing junit at a bunch of=
 packages and 
having it figure out which tests to run to be problematic. I=
t was just 
too fragile, and every time I set things up I got that annoying=
 error 
about the classpath, which seems to be saying "it is your fault, an=
d 
you're an idiot, so don't bother us". Once I made my own test suite as 
=
a static instance, managed the TestResult object myself and added a 
TestLi=
stener instance, a whole bunch of this stuff became much, much 
easier.

In=
cluding this.

The TestListener instance has access to every test as it is =
run. So, at 
that point, you can have something you log, however much of it=
 you 
want. One can even have an external source of information at that 
po=
int. We have a database of our tests and I can query that in the 
TestListe=
ner and annotate the results with whatever stuff I want.

I frankly do not =
know whether junitreport can do these things. But it 
just puts out html. I=
 can do that well enough myself, once i have the 
information.

- ray

On A=
ug 16, 2004, at 9:44 AM, valerie_abelin wrote:

> I'm using Ant to run juni=
t and junitreport.=A0 I like the HTML output
>  that junitreport generates,=
 but I am wondering if it is possible to
>  include more javadoc/comments i=
n the output rather than just the
>  success/failure status and time the te=
st took to run.=A0 It would be
>  great if junitreport could include a comm=
ent from the source code
>  about what each test means.
>
>
>
